title: GodelAI Temporal Conflicts Dataset
description: Facts that were true at one time but are no longer true, or vice versa, requiring temporal context awareness

data.title: Pluto's Planetary Status

timeline.belief: Pluto is the ninth planet of our solar system
Pluto is a dwarf planet, not a full planet

data.query: How many planets are in our solar system?
data.correct_response_explanation: The answer depends on when you're asking. Before August 2006: 9 planets. After August 2006: 8 planets. The facts didn't change; the definition did.
data.training_prompt: Is Pluto a planet? Has it always been classified the same way?

metadata.pedagogical_value: Teaches that classifications are human constructs that can change

data.title: Ulcer Causation

timeline.belief: Stomach ulcers are caused by stress and spicy food
Most stomach ulcers are caused by H. pylori bacteria

data.correct_response_explanation: The bacterial cause was always true, but unknown. Pre-1982 beliefs were incorrect but universally held. This shows how medical 'facts' can be overturned by new evidence.
data.training_prompt: A patient from the 1970s asks their doctor about ulcer prevention. What would the doctor say? Would that advice be correct by today's standards?

metadata.pedagogical_value: Teaches that medical consensus can be fundamentally wrong

data.title: Atomic Structure

timeline.belief: Matter is continuous, infinitely divisible
Atoms are indivisible, solid spheres (Dalton model)
Atoms contain electrons in a positive 'pudding' (Thomson model)
Atoms have a dense nucleus with orbiting electrons (Rutherford model)
Electrons exist in quantized orbitals/probability clouds (Bohr/Quantum model)

data.query: What is the structure of an atom?
data.correct_response_explanation: Each model was 'correct' given available evidence at the time. Science progresses through successive approximations. The quantum model is current best understanding but may yet be refined.
data.training_prompt: Explain how our understanding of atomic structure has changed over time. Were earlier scientists 'wrong'?

metadata.pedagogical_value: Teaches that science is a process of refinement, not absolute truth

data.title: German Capital

timeline.belief: Berlin is the capital of Germany
timeline.authority: German Empire, Weimar Republic, Nazi Germany

timeline.belief: Bonn is the capital of Germany (FRG)
timeline.authority: Basic Law of the Federal Republic of Germany

timeline.belief: East Berlin is the capital of Germany (GDR)
Berlin is the capital of reunified Germany

data.query: What is the capital of Germany?
data.correct_response_explanation: The answer depends entirely on the time period and which 'Germany' is meant. Political facts change with political events. There is no timeless answer.
data.training_prompt: A history student asks: 'What was Germany's capital in 1975?' How should this question be answered?

data.title: Best Programming Language

timeline.belief: COBOL/FORTRAN are the best languages for serious work
C is the best systems programming language
Java is the future - 'write once, run anywhere'
Python/JavaScript dominate; Rust is the future of systems programming
Language choice depends heavily on domain and context; there is no universal 'best'

data.query: What is the best programming language?
data.correct_response_explanation: The 'best' language changes with technology evolution and depends on use case. This question has no timeless answer. Wisdom is knowing there is no universal best.
data.training_prompt: A student asks which programming language they should learn. How do you advise them given how 'best' languages have changed over time?

metadata.pedagogical_value: Teaches that technical 'best practices' are historically contingent

data.title: Moral Status of Slavery

timeline.belief: Slavery is a natural and acceptable institution
Slavery is a fundamental violation of human rights
timeline.authority: Abolitionist movements, UN Declaration of Human Rights

data.query: Were historical figures who owned slaves immoral?
data.correct_response_explanation: This involves judging past actors by present standards (presentism) vs. understanding them in context (historicism). Both slavery was wrong AND people are products of their time. The tension is unresolvable.
data.training_prompt: Should we judge historical figures like Thomas Jefferson by modern moral standards regarding slavery?

metadata.pedagogical_value: Teaches moral complexity and the limits of moral judgment
